article.description: James Thomas had 14 points and 15 rebounds and Texas used relentless defense Wednesday night to beat Texas-Arlington 76-45.
article.headline: Balanced Longhorns wear down Texas-Arlington
article.linkText: Three wins, three different leading scorers for Longhorns
article.story:
AUSTIN, Texas (AP) -- Three wins, three different leading scorers.

The No. 3 Texas Longhorns will take this kind of balance all
season.

James Thomas had 14 points and 15 rebounds and Texas used relentless defense Wednesday night to beat Texas-Arlington 76-45.

"We're not asking one guy to do it for us,'' Longhorns coach Rick Barnes said. "I think we will be a balanced team, which makes you harder to guard.''

Thomas secured his second consecutive double-double and 14th of
his career with more than 16 minutes left in the game. His six
straight points at the start of the second half keyed the decisive
run, helping Texas (3-0) open up a close game.

Derrick Obasohan scored 17 points to lead Texas-Arlington (1-3),
which finished with nearly as many turnovers (29) as rebounds (30).

	   Royal Ivey scored 13 for Texas and Brandon Mouton added 10.

As good as Texas was on the boards and on defense, the Longhorns had their own troubles taking care of the ball and committed 23 turnovers.

"Too many,'' Barnes said. "For us to be the team we want to be, we have got to be a better offensive team.''

T.J. Ford, who led the nation in assists last season, got stripped on the first possession and had an uncharacteristic nine turnovers and just three assists.

"He probably has as tough a night as he's had since he's been
here. It seemed like the harder he tried, the worse he got,''
Barnes said.

The Longhorns made up for the miscues by turning the Mavericks'
mistakes into 31 points and often limiting them to just one shot
when they did manage to get one off.

Texas led 33-25 at halftime.

Thomas opened the second half with two layups and a pair of free
throws as the Longhorns pushed the lead to 39-25. The spurt started
a 17-4 Texas run that made it 50-29.

"The ball just came to me off the rebounds,'' said Thomas, who made 5 of 6 shots. "My biggest deal is rebounding. That's what I like to do.''

Jason Klotz brought the crowd of 8,375 to its feet when he
intercepted a pass near midcourt, tipped it high to himself over a
defender and finished the break with a two-handed dunk.

"That tells you something if our big men are getting out in the
passing lanes, getting steals and finishing it,'' Ivey said.

"They were just so much more talented and bigger and stronger physically,'' said Texas-Arlington coach Eddie McCarter. "They just wore us down.''

The Longhorns continued their 3-point shooting struggles. Texas was 5-of-18 from long range after a 10-for-37 effort in a win last week over Stephen F. Austin.
